title: dbe - data schema for building envelopes
description: This data schema allows to exchange detailed data about building envelopes. In order to make it easy to develop software which For each value, there is exactly one key in the schema to make it easy to develop software which interprets the data correctly. If you should miss any key, please propose it at the website to be included in the next updata of this schema.

internationalString.description: It has been decided to keep everything in English so far. If other languages are included at a later stage, this structure makes it easy.

identifier.description: A Universally Unique Identifier (UUID) or Globally Unique Identifier (GUID) is a 128-bit number. It is used to identify important objects and arrays.

uncertainValue.description: The number for which an uncertainty can be defined by `uncertainty`.

uncertainty.description: The uncertainty of the `uncertainValue` above has the same units as the `uncertainValue`.

confidenceInterval.description: The confidence interval defines the probability that the true value lies within the uncertainty. The first three values belong to the standard errors 68.3% (one sigma), 95.4% (two sigma) or 99.7% (three sigma). If 100.0% is chosen as confidence interval, then it must be guaranteed that the true value can neither be smaller than `uncertainValue`-`uncertainty` nor larger than `uncertainValue`+`uncertainty`.

units.title: This section defines types for numbers with units

meterWithUncertainty.description: Meter is the SI unit for length. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

meterWithoutUncertainty.description: Meter is the SI unit for length. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

nanometerWithoutUncertainty.description: This number represents a length in nanometers. 1 nm equals 10^(-9) meters. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

squareMeterWithUncertainty.description: A square meter (m^2) is a unit for an area. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

squareMillimeterWithUncertainty.description: A square millimeter (mm^2) is a unit for an area. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

squareMillimeterWithoutUncertainty.description: A square millimeter (mm^2) is a unit for an area. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

cubicMeterWithUncertainty.description: A cubic meter is a unit for a volume. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

degree.description: A unit to measure angles. A full rotation equals 360Â°. This type is used for cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

radian.description: A unit to measure angles. A full rotation equals 2*Pi. This type is used for cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

wattWithUncertainty.description: Watt (W) is the SI unit for power. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

wattWithoutUncertainty.description: Watt (W) is the SI unit for power. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

kelvinWithUncertainty.description: Kelvin (K) is the SI unit for temperature. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

kelvinWithoutUncertainty.description: Kelvin (K) is the SI unit for temperature. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

voltWithUncertainty.description: Volt (V) is the SI unit for electric potential. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

voltWithoutUncertainty.description: Volt (V) is the SI unit for electric potential. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

ampereWithUncertainty.description: Ampere (A) is the SI unit for electric current. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

ampereWithoutUncertainty.description: Ampere (A) is the SI unit for electric current. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

ohmWithUncertainty.description: Ohm is the derived SI unit for electric resistance. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

ohmWithoutUncertainty.description: Ohm is the derived SI unit for electric resistance. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

ohmPerMeterWithUncertainty.description: Ohm per meter is a unit for the electric resistance depending on the length. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

ohmPerMeterWithoutUncertainty.description: Ohm per meter is a unit for the electric resistance depending on the length. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

kilogramWithUncertainty.description: Kilogram (also kilogramme, kg) is the SI unit for mass. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

pascalWithoutUncertainty.description: Pascal (Pa) is the SI unit for pressure. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

hertzWithUncertainty.description: Hertz (Hz) is a derived SI unit of frequency. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

hertzWithoutUncertainty.description: Hertz (Hz) is a derived SI unit of frequency. This type is used for rare cases in which the option of an uncertainty is not desired.

kgPerCubicMeterWithUncertainty.description: The density of a material has the SI units kg/m^3. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

JPerKgKwithUncertainty.description: Joule per kilogram and per Kelvin (J/(kg*K)) are the SI units of the specific heat capacity. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

kgPerSecondWithUncertainty.description: Kilogram per second (kg/s) are the SI units of the mass flow. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

wattPerSquareMeterKelvinWithUncertainty.description: Watt per square meter and per kelvin (W/(m^2*K) are the SI units of a heat transfer coefficient. With this type, the uncertainty can be defined.

standard.title: Standards are a special kind publications. Therefore their data structure is different from publications.

id.description: The id represents this specific standard.

standardizers.description: Standards typically do not name authors, but an institution or several institutions which created the standard. The institutions are identified by their abbreviation.

numeration.description: A standard may be named `ISO 52022-1` or `ASTM E2387`. While `ISO` and `ASTM` are the abbreviations for the standardizers, `52022` and `2387` are the main numbers. `E` is the prefix and `1` is the postfix which may indicate for example a part number. This classification facilitates the search, because there are multiple ways to refer to a standard.

year.description: It is important to define the year in which the standard was issued because there can be relevant updates of one standard.

section.description: The section of the standard to which the reference refers to.

standard.description: `ISO 52022` is an example of the abbreviation of a standardizer and the main number of the identifier.

installed.title: This geometric definition of the dimensions refers to the installation of the component in a building envelope and a view perpendicular to the building envelope. The dimensions can be used to define a bounding box which includes all parts of the component. If a component can be installed in different ways, more than one set of dimensions can be defined.

height.description: The height of the component along the vertical axis of the building envelope. It has the units meter.

width.description: The width of the component along the horizontal axis of the building envelope. It has the units meter.

depth.description: The depth of the component along the axis perpendicular to the building envelope. It has the units meter.

independent.title: When the dimensions of a component are defined independent of a specific installation or coordinate system, then the dimensions can only be sorted by their values. The dimensions can be used to define a bounding box which includes all parts of the component.

smallest.description: The smallest dimension of the component. It has the units meter.

intermediate.description: The dimension of the component which is larger the `smallest` and smaller than `largest`. It has the units meter.

largest.description: The largest dimension of the component. It has the units meter.

basics.title: This section presents definitions to describe the geometry of a component.

centerOfGravity.description: Definition of the center of gravity of the component

dimensions.description: Height, width and depth of the component.

coordinateSystem.description: Definition of the coordinate systems to which the other coordinates refer to.

bodies.description: This array lists all the bodies of which the component consists.

file.description: Instead of or in addition to the keys above, a file can be used to define the geometry of the component.

LOD.title: The Level of Development or Level of Detail (LOD) is used to describe how accurate the reality is modelled. As geometry/LOD refers to geometry, it is sometimes also called Level of Geometry.

items.description: This integer indicates the LOD according to the definition of the reference below.

reference.description: This reference defines the LOD which is indicated above.

point.title: This section defines a point according to the definition of a coordinate system elsewhere.

coordinateSystem.title: Definition of the coordinate system of the data set

reference.description: The coordinate system needs to be well defined. If no suitable reference exists, please create a new publication in the database.

items.description: Often, a right-handed cartesian coordinate system is used.

NURBS.title: A non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) surface is a very general way to define a surface. It is created by two NURBS curves.
A non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) is a very general way to define a curve.

degree.description: The degree of a NURBS curve defines the polynomial degree of the basis functions of the curve. For degree=1, the curve is a linear interpolation between the control points.

controlPoints.title: The control points have a strong influence on the shape of the curve.

items.description: If the curve is 3D, the 3D points are appropriate. For 2D curves, the value for the z-axis should be 0.

weights.description: The weight of a control points determines its influences on the shape of the curve.

controlPoints.description: The number of control points plus the degree plus 1 has to be equal to the number of knots.

items.description: Each knot is a number which is either equal or larger than the preceding knot. Although usually the control points are used to shape the curve, the knots could also be used for this purpose. The first and last knot are usually repeated so that the curve ends exactly at these points.

knots.description: The number of control points plus the degree plus 1 has to be equal to the number of knots.

brep.title: Boundary representation (brep) defines a component by the surfaces between solid and non-solid.
brep.description: This array list all surfaces between solid and non-solid of the component.

assembly.title: Components can either consist of one element or of an assembly of elements. This section is used to define assemblies of elements. Each item of the array defines one component of the assembly

id.description: The id represents a specific componet of the assembly.

geometry.description: The reference defines the geometry of the component.

explanation.description: An explanation with more details about the component

chemicalElements.description: In this array, the most important chemical elements can be named by the two letters of the periodic table of elements.

refractiveIndex.description: The refractive index is needed to calculate to calculate the path of irradiance through different materials.

density.description: The density is needed to calculate the weigth of the layer.

constants.title: This section collect all constants which are specific for components of the category materials.

possiblePositions.description: PossiblePositions defines where the material can be used.

constants.title: This section collect all constants which are specific for components of the category layers.

possiblePositions.description: PossiblePositions defines where the layer can be used.

items.description: The orientation axis is important for example for venetian blinds.

slat.title: For example venetian blinds consist of many slats. This section is used to define constants for such slats.

pitch.description: Pitch is the distance between the rotation axis' of two neighbouring slats.

crownHeight.description: When a slat lies on a horizontal surface, the Crown Height is the distance between this surface and the heighest points of the slats.

oneOf.description: Usually, the shape of a slat is best described by a 2D curve of its cross section.
If the shape of the slats needs to be defined in 3D, a surface can be used.

tilt.description: For horizontal slats, the slat tilt angle is measured from the horizontal plane. 0Â° means fully open slats and 70Â° almost closed slats.

maximumClosing.description: The maximum closing angle is the highest possible slat tilt angle, typically because the slats tough each other.

angles.title: This sections defines angles which are helpful to characterize building envelopes.

tilt.description: For horizontal slats, the slat tilt angle is measured from the horizontal plane. 0Â° means fully open slats and 70Â° almost closed slats.

maximumClosing.description: The maximum closing angle is the highest possible slat tilt angle, typically because the slats tough each other.

constants.title: This section collect all constants which are specific for components of the category units.

gaps.title: The gaps for example between a blind and the frame can be important for example regarding glare.

dTop.description: dTop is usually a distance at the top of the unit, but is defined exactly in the reference below.

dGlass.description: dGlass is usually a distance to the glass pane, but is defined exactly in the reference below.

reference.description: This reference defines all parameters of this object.

source.title: The source data is the data which has been the starting point and on which a method was applied by the creator of the new data set.

id.description: The id represents the data source.

name.description: A data set can have a name.

explanation.description: This string can explain the source data for humans.

origin.title: Origin can be used to define how the data was created.

creator.description: The creator of the new dataset is identified here.

method.description: The method which has been applied by the creator on the source data is identified here. This method may be a combination of submethods.

source.description: The source data has been the starting point for the creator. If the method is a measurement, there may be no source data.

database.description: The database, where the source data and the method can be found, is identified here.

efficiencies.title: For the conversion of energy into another, this section provides definitions for effiencies.

photovoltaic.description: The photovoltaic efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide electric power.

solarThermal.description: The solar thermal efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide heat.

inverter.description: The efficiency of an inverter which converts for example direct current into alternating current.

bidirectional.title: This array defines connections between two components without defining a direction for these connections.

connectionType.description: The id defines the type of the connection.

id1.description: Id1 represents the first component which is connected to the component represented by id2.

id2.description: Id1 represents the second component which is connected to the component represented by id1.

length.description: The length of this connection in meters.

resistance.description: The electric resistance of the connection in ohms.

currentVoltage.title: The current-voltage characteristic can be important for example for photovoltaics.

V.description: The electric potential difference in volts.

photovoltaic.title: This section provides a structure for data about photovoltaic modules which convert irradiance into electricity.

module.title: A photovoltaic (PV) module consists of PV cells which are connected and turn irradiance into electric power.

coordinateSystem.description: The coordinate system is defined by a reference to a publication or standard.

longitudinal.description: Maximum number of cells along the longest side of the PV module.

transversal.description: Maximum number of cells along the shorter side of the PV module.

all.description: The number of all cells of the PV module.

specifications.title: This array defines which type of cells is used in the PV module.

id.description: The id represents one type of PV cells.

explanation.description: This string can explain the cell to humans.

efficiency.description: The effiency of the cell is measured at standard test conditions.

nominal.description: The nominal power of the cell is measured independently at standard test conditions in watts.

effective.description: The effective nominal power of a cell is the nominal power of the module divided by the number of cells.

width.description: If the cell has more or less the form of a square, then the width between two parallel sides is helpful to calculate how many cells fit into one module.

currentVoltage.description: The current-voltage characteristic is important to calculate the PV performance for conditions other than the standard test conditions.

items.description: A photovoltaic cell can have one or more of these categories. For example, Copper indium gallium selenide PV is a thin film and solid state PV technology and would be described by the corresponding six items in the array.

list.title: This array lists each cells of the PV module.

id.description: The id represents one specific cell in the photovoltaic module. It is used to define connections to other parts of the PV module.

cellType.description: The id represents one type of PV cells as defined above.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry and location of the cell.

spacings.title: If there are the same spaces between cells parallel to one side of the module, then they can be defined here.

longitudinal.description: The distance between two neighboring cells parallel to the longest side of the PV module in metre (m).

transversal.description: The distance between two neighboring cells parallel to the shorter side of the PV module in metre (m).

all.description: The number of all diodes in this PV module.

specifications.title: This array defines the type of diodes which are used in the the PV module.

id.description: The id represents one type of diodes which is used in the the PV module. The id is used to define connections to other parts of the PV module

explanation.description: This string can explain the cell to humans.

list.title: This array lists the diodes of the PV module. They are used to bypass shaded cells which would otherwise dissipate energy.

id.description: The id represents one specific diode of the PV module. The id is used to define connections to other parts of the PV module

diodeType.description: The id defines the type of the diode.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry and location of the diode.

all.description: The number of all connections in this PV module.

specifications.title: This array defines the type of electric connections which are used in the the PV module.

id.description: The id represents one type of connections which is used in the the PV module. The id is used to define connections to other parts of the PV module

explanation.description: This string can explain the connection type to humans.

resistancePerLength.description: The electric resistance of the connection per length of the connection in ohms per meter.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the connection.

list.description: This section defines a list of all connections between cells and between cells and diodes.

category.description: If the connections are in series or parallel, this can be defined here.

layers.title: PV modules typically consist of several layers, for example a glass pane, a lamination material and the PV cells.

all.description: The number of all layers in this PV module.

material.description: This sections defines the material of the layer

materialProperties.description: All properties which depend on the material in general and not on the specific component.

categories.description: Typically, a PV module consists of a front cover layer, a front embedding layer, a cell layer, a rear embedding layer and a backing layer. The layer can therefore be defined by multiple strings.

thickness.description: The thickness of this layer as part of the module.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry and location of the layer including its dimensions.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the component.

id.description: The id represents one type of junction boxes which is used in the the PV module.
The id represents one specific diode of the PV module. The id is used to define connections to other parts of the PV module

junctionBoxType.description: The id defines the type of junction box.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry and location of the junction box.

grounding.description: This array defines whether the electric plus or minus is connected to the ground.

connectionCables.title: The connection cables are outside of the PV module to connect it to other PV modules.

id.description: The id represents a type of connection cables.

crossSection.description: The cross-sectional area of the connection cable in square millimeters.

positive.description: The length of the connection cable with the electric plus sign.

negative.description: The length of the connection cable with the electric minus sign.

id.description: The id represents the type of connector with which the connection cable is connected to another PV module.

name.description: The name of the connector type.

frame.title: PV modules often have a frame which increases the mechanical stability of the module.

material.description: This sections defines the material of the layer

materialProperties.description: All properties which depend on the material in general and not on the specific component.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry and location of the cell.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the component.

nominal.description: The nominal power is measured at the maximum power point of the module under standard test conditions.

tolerance.description: The tolerance of the nominal power of the module in percent. For example, '5' means, that the nominal power can be 5% larger or smaller than the value provided above.

temperatureCoefficient.description: When the temperature increases compared to standard test conditions, the nominal power changes. The temperature coefficient has the unit percent per Kelvin (%/K) to quantifies this change.

guarantee.title: This section defines if a guarantee is available specifically for the nominal power of the module. It is defined by fractions of the nominal power until a certain number of of years. For example, `years`=10 and `percentage`=90 means that 10 year old modules have at least 90% of their nominal power. `percentage`=0 means that no guarantee for the power is provided.

years.description: This number defines the amount of years until which a certain minimum percentage of the nominal power is guaranteed.

percentage.description: This number defines which fraction of the nominal power in percent is guaranteed as minimum after the amount of years which are defined above.

angleDependency.title: The nominal power usually depends on the direction of irradiance. In general, the `incidenceDirectionModifier` can characterize this dependency on the direction. If the dependency has a rotational symmetry regarding the incidence angle, `incidenceAngelModifier` should be provided.

incidenceAngleModifier.title: If the nominal power has an incidence angle symmetry regarding the direct irradiance, then this Incidence Angle Modifier (IAM) can be defined and plotted as a curve. It modifies the nominal power depending on the incidence angle.

IAM.description: `IAM` defines the value of the incidence angle modifier at the angle defined by `incidence`.

incidenceDirectionModifier.title: If the nominal power depends on the direction of the irradiance, this modifier can be multiplied to the nominal power.

direction.description: The section defines the direction of the incident radiation.

modifier.description: For the direction above, this `modifier` can be multiplied with the nominal power to determine the power at a this direction of incidence.

nominal.description: The nominal voltage is measured at the maximum power point of the module under standard test conditions.

openCircuit.description: The open circuit voltage is measured under standard test conditions without connecting the module to an electric circuit.

temperatureCoefficient.description: When the temperature increases compared to standard test conditions, the open circuit voltage changes. The temperature coefficient has the unit percent per Kelvin (%/K) to quantifies this change.

maximumSystem.description: The voltage of a PV system made with these modules should stay below this maximum system voltage.

nominal.description: The nominal current is measured at the maximum power point of the module under standard test conditions.

shortCircuit.description: The short circuit current is measured under standard test conditions with the module connected to an electric circuit which has an electric resistance of zero.

temperatureCoefficient.description: When the temperature increases compared to standard test conditions, the short circuit current changes. The temperature coefficient has the unit percent per Kelvin (%/K) to quantifies this change.

fillFactor.description: The fill factor is a measure of quality of a solar cell. It is the power at the maximum powerpoint divided by the open circuit voltage and the short circuit current.

efficiency.description: The effiency of the module is measured at standard test conditions.

weight.description: The weigth of the PV module.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry of the PV module including the dimensions width, height and depth (thickness).

safety.title: This section defines data about the safety of PV modules.

fire.title: This section defines the fire safety class of the PV module depending on the region for which the class is valid.

EN.title: This section defines the fire safety class according to the regulations of the European Union. EN 13501-1 defines the categories as well as the additional classification for smoke development and burning drops falling from the component.

mechanical.title: Mechanical load tests verify that a module can withstand wind and snow.

rated.description: The maximum rated pressure in Pascal.

tested.description: The maximum tested pressure in Pascal.

rated.description: The maximum rated suction in Pascal.

tested.description: The maximum tested suction in Pascal.

reference.description: The reference defines for example the standard according to which the mechanical test was performed.

oneOf.description: noPerformanceDetermined defines that no tests of the mechanical loads are available.

reference.description: If the PV module passed a hail test, then the reference can refer for example to a standard according to which the test was performed.

oneOf.description: noPerformanceDetermined defines that no hail test results are available.

temperatures.title: This section defines the operating temperatures.

minimum.description: The minimum operating temperature in Kelvin (K).

operating.description: The operating temperature of the cells under standard test conditions and in Kelvin (K).

maximum.description: The maximum operating temperature in Kelvin (K).

guarantee.title: This section defines if a a general guarantee for the product. It is defined by the number of years and can refer to a publication or standard for details. `years`=0 means that no guarantee is provided. It is an array so that references for different number of years can be defined.

years.description: This number defines the number of years for which the manufacturer offers a guarantee for this module.

reference.description: The reference can define a publication or standard with details of the guarantee.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the component.

uValue.description: The U value, also known as thermal transmittance, characterizes the rate of heat transfer through this PV module.

inverter.title: Usually, one inverter converts the direct current (DC) of the modules into alternating current (AC).

id.description: The id represents the inverter.

amounts.title: This section is used to define the number of MPP trackers and DC input ports.

trackers.description: The number of maximum-power-point (MPP) trackers which the inverter provides.

inputs.description: The number of DC input ports which the inverter provides. To each input port, one string of PV modules can be connected.

maximum.description: The maximum input power from the PV modules to the inverter in watts.

nominal.description: The nominal output power of the inverter in watts.

maximum.description: The maximum output power of the inverter in watts.

normalized.description: The output power at maximum efficiency divided by the nominal output power. It is a number without units.

night.description: The power demand of the inverter at night in watts.

minimum.description: When the input voltage decreases below this value, the inverter switches from operation into standby.

start.description: When the input voltage increase above this value, the inverter switches from standby to operation.

maximum.description: The maximum input voltage for the inverter.

minimum.description: The minimum frequency of the AC output of the inverter in hertz.

maximum.description: The maximum frequency of the AC output of the inverter in hertz.
The maximum input current for the inverter in amperes.

shortCircuit.description: The maximum short circuit current of the the inverter in amperes.

nominal.description: The nominal AC output current of the inverter in amperes.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry of the inverter including the dimensions width, height and depth (thickness).

safety.title: This section defines data about the safety of the inverter.

electric.title: This section defines the electric safety of the inverter.

IPcode.title: This section defines the electric safety according to the International Protection Marking, also called Ingress Protection Marking. Codes between IPXX and IP69K are defined. `standard` defines which standard defines the details of the of the IP code. `firstDigit` defines the protection against solid particles and the `secondDigit` against liquid ingress. `thirdDigit` is optional and defines the access to dangerous active parts. `fourthDigit` is optional, too, and can define additional information.

applianceClass.title: The appliance protection classes define which protective-earth connection requirements are fulfilled.

temperatures.title: This section defines the operating temperatures.

minimum.description: The minimum ambient temperature in Kelvin (K) for the inverter to operate.

maximum.description: The maximum ambient temperature in Kelvin (K) for the inverter to operate.
The maximum efficiency of this inverter. The efficiency has no units.

European.description: The efficiency of this inverter according to the european regulations. The efficiency has no units.

system.title: A photovoltaic (PV) system consists of PV modules which are connected and turn irradiance into electric power.

coordinateSystem.description: The coordinate system is defined by a reference to a publication or standard.

modules.title: This array defines the modules of the PV system.

id.description: The id represents one specific PV module in the PV system. It is used to define connections to other parts of the PV system.

moduleType.description: The id represents one type of PV modules.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry and location of the PV module.

diodeTypes.title: This array defines the type of diodes which are used in the the PV module.

id.description: The id represents one type of diodes which is used in the the PV module. The id is used to define connections to other parts of the PV module

explanation.description: This string can explain the cell to humans.

diodes.title: This array defines the diodes of the PV system. They are used to bypass shaded cells which would otherwise dissipate energy.

id.description: The id represents one specific diode of the PV system. The id is used to define connections to other parts of the PV system

diodeType.description: The id defines the type of the diode.

geometry.description: This section defines the geometry and location of the diode.

connectionTypes.title: This array defines the type of electric connections which are used in this PV system.

id.description: The id represents one type of connections which is used in the the PV system. The id is used to define connections to other parts of the PV system

explanation.description: This string can explain the connection type to humans.

crossSection.description: The cross-sectional area of the connection cable in square millimeters.

resistancePerLength.description: The electric resistance of the connection per length of the connection in ohms per meter.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the connection.

connections.description: This section defines the connections between cells and between modules, diodes and inverters.

inverters.title: Usually, one inverter converts the direct current (DC) of the modules into alternating current (AC). But also several inverters could be used.

basics.title: The array is used to define sets of calorimetric data.

id.description: The id represents a specific calorimetric data set.

name.description: If the calorimetric data set has a name, it can be indicated here.

explanation.description: This string can explain humans the calorimetric data set.

warnings.description: Some calorimetric data may easily be misinterpreted. The warnings contain critical information for users to avoid typical mistakes.

origin.description: For traceability, the origin of the data can be defined.

approvals.description: If the calorimetric data is approved by stakeholders, a signature can be provided.

created.description: When the calorimetric data was created.

valid.description: From when and until when the data is valid.

constants.description: Parameters which do not change during the individual measurements can be indicated here as constants. This reduces the file size.

file.description: The optical data can be provided as a file. If the data is provided as a file and as explicit values below, than it MUST be the same data only in different formats. If one data is derived from another data, it MUST be stored as separate items in the array optical/basics and origin SHOULD be used to identify the method of derivation.

fluxes.title: This array defines the energy fluxes between the sample and its surroundings.

name.description: The name of the part of the surroundings. If neither exterior nor interior or lateral fits, choose other and describe it in the explanation below.

explanation.description: This string explains humans the calorimetric data set.

convection.title: Convective heat transfer is defined by the temperature difference and the heat transfer coefficient.

flux.description: The heat flux is driven by the temperature differences. Positive heat flux means heat flux towards the sample. It is meaured in watts.

surrounding.description: The average temperature of this part of the surroundings.

sample.description: The average temperature of the part of the sample which faces this part of the surroundings.

coefficient.description: The heat transfer coefficient equals the heat flux divided by the temperature difference. It has the unit watt per square meter per kelvin.

fluid.title: If heat is transfered to the sample by a fluid circuit, this heat flux can be defined by the following properties.

flux.description: This heat flux is caused by the temperature difference between the fluid inlet of the sample and the fluid outlet. It is meaured in watts.

inlet.description: The average temperature of the fluid at the inlet of the sample.

outlet.description: The average temperature of the fluid at the outlet of the sample.

massFlow.description: The mass flow of the fluid circuit which enters and leaves the sample in kilogram per second.

specificHeatCapacity.description: The specific heat capacity of the fluid in joules per kilogram per Kelvin.

flux.description: The irradiance is determined on the surface of the sample. Positive irradiance means irradiance towards the sample. It is meaured in watts.

direction.description: The direction of the irradiance on the sample.

flux.description: The electric energy supplied to the sample. Positive electric energy means that it is delivered to the sample.

currentVoltage.description: The current-voltage characteristic can be important for example for photovoltaics. It can also be used just to define just one current and one voltage.

results.title: The results of a calorimetric measurement depend on the reference area. This array can defined results for different reference areas.

area.title: The results depend on the area of the component which is used to calculate the results. This section defines this area.

category.description: (i) `centre` means that the results are valid for the centre of the component without influence by the frame. This is important for example for glazings. (ii) `outerDimensions` means that the whole area of the outer dimensions of the component is considered for the results. (iii) `irradiatedAbsorber` means that the area of the photovoltaic or solar thermal absober, which is irradiated by direct irradiance, is used to calculate the results. (iv) For the case of direct irradiance, `projectedIrradiatedAbsorber` projects the directly irradiated absorber area to a plane which is perpendicular to the direct irradiance. (v) If none of the other categories apply, `explanation` below must be used to describe the category.

explanation.description: If `other` is chosen as category above, the area needs to be defined by this explanation. For any other category, the explanation can add details.

uValue.description: The U value, also known as thermal transmittance, can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior.

gValue.description: The g value is also known as Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC), Solar Factor or Total Solar Energy Transmittance. It can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior. It has typically values between 0 and 1 and is a measure for the fraction of solar energy which enters the building.

photovoltaic.description: The photovoltaic efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide electric power. This efficiency has no units.

solarThermal.description: The solar thermal efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide heat.

conditions.description: Either a measurement aims at quasi-stationary conditions or at dynamic conditions where the values change over time.

coordinateSystem.description: The coordinate system is defined by a reference to a publication or standard.

uValue.description: The U value, also known as thermal transmittance, can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior.

gValue.description: The g value is also known as Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC), Solar Factor or Total Solar Energy Transmittance. It can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior. It has typically values between 0 and 1 and is a measure for the fraction of solar energy which enters the building.

basics.title: The array is used to define sets of optical data.

id.description: The id represents the optical data set.

name.description: If the optical data set has a name, it can be indicated here.

explanation.description: This string can explain humans the optical data set.

warnings.description: Some optical data may easily be misinterpreted. The warnings contain critical information for users to avoid typical mistakes.

origin.description: For traceability, the origin of the data can be defined.

approvals.description: If the optical data is approved by stakeholders, a signature can be provided.

created.description: When the optical data was created.

valid.description: From when and until when the data is valid.

constants.description: Parameters which do not change during the individual measurements can be indicated here as constants. This reduces the file size.

file.description: The optical data can be provided as a file. If the data is provided as a file and as explicit values below, than it MUST be the same data only in different formats. If one data is derived from another data, it MUST be stored as separate items in the array optical/basics and origin SHOULD be used to identify the method of derivation.

dataPoints.title: This section provides a list of all data points of this optical data.

items.title: Each optical data point consists of a definition of the incident radiation, the variables of the component, the emergent rediation and the optical results.

incidence.description: This section defines the incident radiation on the component.

variables.description: This section defines the variable which change between some data points. Parameters which stay constant can be indicated above constants in order to reduce the file size.

emergence.description: This section defines the radiation which emerges from the component.

results.description: Results can be for example the transmittance and the reflectance.

direction.title: This section defines a direction for example of the radiation on a sample. The array offers different ways of describing the direction, for example by two angles.

polar.description: In the spherical coordinate system, the polar angle is measured from a fixed axis such as the z-axis of a cartesian coordinate system.

azimuth.description: In the spherical coordinate system, the azimuth angle is measured from orthogonal projextion of the direction on a reference plane such as the plane between the x- and y-axis of a cartestian coordinate system.

xz.description: If the z-axis is normal to the building envelope and the x-axis directs for example vertically upwards in a facade,then the angle xz is measured from the z-axis towards the x-axis. 80Â° is then from the facade almost vertically upwards and -10Â° means from the facade downwards, but almost horizontal.

yz.description: If the z-axis is normal to the building envelope, the x-axis directs for example vertically upwards in a facade and the y-axis is horizontal in an right-handed coordinate system, then the angle yz is measured from the z-axis towards the y axis. From the facade looking to the exterior, 80Â° means a direction far right, almost parallel to the facade. -10Â° means from the facade to exterior slightly left, but almost perpendiculat to the facade.

incidence.description: If the sample has a rotational symmetry, then the incidence angle is sufficient to define the direction.

profile.description: If the sample has a profile angle symmetry, then the profile angle is sufficient to define the direction.

anyOf.title: This section should be used for cases with nearnormal or hemispherical incidence or emergence. For other cases, the other items of the array `direction` should be used.
anyOf.description: Nearnormal means a direction almost perpendicular to the sample surface. Hemispherical means all directions into the hemisphere above the sample surface, for example when there is the same irradiance from all directions. Diffuse means all directions except the nearnormal direction. For example, the nearnormal-hemispherical transmittance is always equal to the nearnormal-nearnormal transmittance plus the nearnormal-diffuse transmittance.

formatting.description: The definition of the format of the array below needs to specify how the items of the array can be interpreted as a list of directions. For example, the format can define that the list consists of pairs of polar and azimuth angles.

items.description: In order to reduze the size of the data, multiple directions can be entered as a list/array.

polarisation.title: Polarization is a characteristic of radiation which can influence the transmittance and the reflectance. Radiation can be polarized linearly or circular.

s.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field perpendicular to the plane of incidence of the radiation on the sample. s is usually between 0 and 1. Only in raw data there may be exceptions because of the uncertainty. However, s can never be below 0-uncertainty or larger than 1+uncertainty.

p.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field parallel to the plane of incidence of the radiation on the sample. p is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

l.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field rotating in a left-hand sense with respect to the direction of radiation. l is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

r.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field rotating in a right-hand sense with respect to the direction of radiation. r is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

wavelengths.title: This section offers three options to define the wavelength of radiation: either as a single wavelength, as an array of wavelenghts or as an integral over many wavelengths.

wavelength.description: A single wavelength in nanometers. If necessary, the uncertainty can be defined under `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/bandwidth`.

items.description: An list of wavelengths, each in nanometers. If the uncertainty is identical, it can be defined under `#/definitions/wavelength/range/bandwidth`. If the uncertainty is not identical and relevant, the array should not be used.

integral.description: This flag indicates that an integral over many wavelenthgs is considered here. Under `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/spectrum`, the spectrum can be specified over which the integral result is calculated.

range.title: The range can either define the bandwidth or amplification factor of measuring a single wavelength or an entire spectrum of wavenlengths which is measured at the same time.

bandwidth.description: When `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/wavelength` is defined as the center, bandwidth defines is the range of wavelengths around it. It can be interpreted as the uncertainty of the `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/wavelength`.

amplificationFactor.description: range/bandwidth is difficult to measure. Often it is easier to determine the amplificationFactor as a measure for the uncertainty of the `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/wavelength`.

spectrum.description: If `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/integral` is true, then `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/spectrum` identifies the spectrum of wavelengths over which the integral result is be calculated. For further specification of the spectrum, please search for the applied `#/definitions/standard`.

incidence.title: This section defines the incident radiation on a sample. It consists of the direction of the irradiance, its polarization, the wavelenthgs and the range of the wavelengths.

emergence.title: This section defines the emergent radiation on a sample. It consists of the direction of the emergence, its polarization, the wavelenthgs and the range of the wavelengths.

parameters.title: This section defines parameters for optical measurements and simulations. The parameters are lated used either as optical/constants or optical/variables.

reference.description: This reference defines any treatment performed on the sample before measurement.
This reference defines the location of measurement on the sample.
This reference defines the polarization sensitivity of the receiver of the optical measurement.

instrumentSignature.description: The instrument signature is defined as the mean scatter leel detected when there is no sample scatter present.

normalization.description: The normalization methods absolute, relative, specular and diffuse reflectance are defined by ASTM E2387-05:2011.

coordinateSystem.description: The coordinate system is defined by a reference to a publication or standard.

referenceSample.description: Optical measurements can depend on the reference sample which is used. The reference defines this reference sample.

spot.description: The reference defines the size and profile of the irradiance on the sample.

tilt.description: The tilt angle for example of venetian blinds.

parameters.description: If a parameter is a constant during this set of optical measurements, it is defined here and CANNOT be defined in `#/definitions/optical/variables`.
If a parameter is a variable during this set of optical measurements, it is defined here and CANNOT be defined in `#/definitions/optical/constants`.

results.title: This section defines the results of the optical measurement or simulation under the specified boundary conditions.

transmittance.description: Transmittance is the ratio between the irradiance which is transmitted through the sample and the irradiance on the the sample. It has values between 0 and 1. Exceptions are usually due to measurement uncertainty.

reflectance.description: Reflectance is the ratio between the irradiance which is reflected by the sample and the irradiance on the the sample.

oneOf.title: BSDF means Bidirectional Scattering Distribution Function. It is defined as the emergent radiation PER STERADIAN divided by the incident radiation AND THE COSINE OF THE ANGLE OF EMERGENCE. Bidirectional means that the direction of the incident radiation on the sample is defined and also the direction of the emergent radiation to the detector. BSDF data often involves many data points with various combinations of incidence and emergence directions. This section defines the results of the BSDF measurement or simulation under the specified boundary conditions.

BTDF.description: BTDF means Bidirectional Transmittance Distribution Function. It is defined as the  radiation per steradian which is transmitted in a certain direction and divided by the incident radiation and the cosine of the angle of emergence.

BRDF.description: BRDF means Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function. It is defined as the  radiation per steradian which is transmitted in a certain direction and divided by the incident radiation and the cosine of the angle of emergence.

component.title: This section collects the definitions regarding components of building envelopes

basics.title: This section collects the basic definitions about a component.

id.description: This id represents the component

explanation.description: An explanation with more details about the component

version.description: The id represents the version of the component.

categories.description: The component is categorized in order to facilitate queries.

constants.description: There are two types of parameters: constants are defined here and do not change in one data set. Variables may change for each data point. Therefore, variables are stored close to the data points.

owner.description: The URI and description of the owner of the component

manufacturer.description: The URI and description of the manufacturer of the component

developer.description: The URI and description of the institution or person which developed the component

approvals.description: If the dataset for this component has been approved by an institution, this approval is specified here.

available.description: Since when and until when the component has been available

optical.description: All optical data of the data set is stored in this section. For example the transmittance and reflectance with specific boundary conditions.

calorimetric.description: All calorimetric data of the data set is stored in this section. For example the U value, the g value (or Solar Heat Gain Coefficient).

photovoltaic.title: This section defines all data about building envelopes which can convert irradiance into electric power.

module.description: If the component can turn irradiance into DC current, it can be named BIPV module and defined here.

inverter.description: If the component can convert DC to AC, it can be named inverter and be defined by this section.

system.description: If the building component consists of several PV modules and an inverter, it can be named BIPV system and defined here.

items.description: A building envelope component can be a plain material, a layer in a stack of layers of a unit including frame effects. While some components are used e.g. only as materials, other components can be used in several categories.
Components of the category material can have the subcategories of this array which further specifies the material.
Components of the category layer can have the subcategories of this array which further specifies the layer.
Components of the category unit can have the subcategories of this array which further specifies the unit.

version.title: This section provides definitions about a version of a component.

id.description: This id represents a specific version of a component.

name.description: If the version of the component has a specific name or version number, it can be entered here.

explanation.description: Here the version can be described in free text.

owner.description: The URI and description of the owner of the component

manufacturer.description: The URI and description of the manufacturer of the component

developer.description: The URI and description of the institution or person which developed the component

available.description: Since when and until when the component has been available

constants.title: For one dataset, the constants of the component stay the same while the variables may change between different data points.

geometry.title: This section defines the geometry of the component which can either be an assembly or a single component.

airPermeability.description: The air permeability defines how easy air can flow through the component.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the component.

cutOff.description: The cutoff angle is an angle above which the incident radiation cannot cause glare.

chemicalElements.description: In this array, the most important chemical elements can be named by the two letters of the periodic table of elements.

material.description: If the component is a material, the material-specific constants can be named here.

layer.description: If the component is a layer, the layer-specific constants can be named here.

unit.description: If the component is a unit, the unit-specific constants can be named here.

components.title: This section defines data about components of a solar building envelope. It is an array so that various data sets about one or more components can be added as items. One component may consist of subcomponents.
